DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

VpcEndpointIds.documentation: The IDs of one or more VPC endpoints.

Unsuccessful.documentation: Information about the endpoints that were not rejected, if applicable.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

VpcPeeringConnectionId.documentation: The ID of the VPC peering connection.

Return.documentation: Returns true if the request succeeds; otherwise, it returns an error.

AllocationId.documentation: [EC2-VPC] The allocation ID. Required for EC2-VPC.

PublicIp.documentation: [EC2-Classic] The Elastic IP address. Required for EC2-Classic.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

HostIds.documentation: The IDs of the Dedicated Hosts to release.

Successful.documentation: The IDs of the Dedicated Hosts that were successfully released.

Unsuccessful.documentation: The IDs of the Dedicated Hosts that could not be released, including an error message.

AssociationId.documentation: The ID of the existing IAM instance profile association.

IamInstanceProfileAssociation.documentation: Information about the IAM instance profile association.

AssociationId.documentation: The ID of the current association between the original network ACL and the subnet.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

NetworkAclId.documentation: The ID of the new network ACL to associate with the subnet.

CidrBlock.documentation: The IPv4 network range to allow or deny, in CIDR notation (for example 172.16.0.0/24).

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

Egress.documentation:
Indicates whether to replace the egress rule.

Default: If no value is specified, we replace the ingress rule.

IcmpTypeCode.documentation: ICMP protocol: The ICMP or ICMPv6 type and code. Required if specifying protocol 1 (ICMP) or protocol 58 (ICMPv6) with an IPv6 CIDR block.

Ipv6CidrBlock.documentation: The IPv6 network range to allow or deny, in CIDR notation (for example 2001:bd8:1234:1a00::/64).

PortRange.documentation: TCP or UDP protocols: The range of ports the rule applies to. Required if specifying protocol 6 (TCP) or 17 (UDP).

Protocol.documentation: The protocol number. A value of "-1" means all protocols. If you specify "-1" or a protocol number other than "6" (TCP), "17" (UDP), or "1" (ICMP), traffic on all ports is allowed, regardless of any ports or ICMP types or codes that you specify. If you specify protocol "58" (ICMPv6) and specify an IPv4 CIDR block, traffic for all ICMP types and codes allowed, regardless of any that you specify. If you specify protocol "58" (ICMPv6) and specify an IPv6 CIDR block, you must specify an ICMP type and code.

RuleAction.documentation: Indicates whether to allow or deny the traffic that matches the rule.

RuleNumber.documentation: The rule number of the entry to replace.

DestinationCidrBlock.documentation: The IPv4 CIDR address block used for the destination match. The value that you provide must match the CIDR of an existing route in the table.

DestinationIpv6CidrBlock.documentation: The IPv6 CIDR address block used for the destination match. The value that you provide must match the CIDR of an existing route in the table.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

EgressOnlyInternetGatewayId.documentation: [IPv6 traffic only] The ID of an egress-only internet gateway.

GatewayId.documentation: The ID of an internet gateway or virtual private gateway.

InstanceId.documentation: The ID of a NAT instance in your VPC.

NatGatewayId.documentation: [IPv4 traffic only] The ID of a NAT gateway.

VpcPeeringConnectionId.documentation: The ID of a VPC peering connection.

AssociationId.documentation: The association ID.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

RouteTableId.documentation: The ID of the new route table to associate with the subnet.

DestinationCidrBlock.documentation: The CIDR range used for the destination match. Routing decisions are based on the most specific match.

Blackhole.documentation: Indicates whether traffic matching this route is to be dropped.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

Description.documentation: Descriptive text about the health state of your instance.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

EndTime.documentation: The time at which the reported instance health state ended.

ReasonCodes.documentation:
The reason codes that describe the health state of your instance.

  • instance-stuck-in-state: My instance is stuck in a state.

  • unresponsive: My instance is unresponsive.

  • not-accepting-credentials: My instance is not accepting my credentials.

  • password-not-available: A password is not available for my instance.

  • performance-network: My instance is experiencing performance problems that I believe are network related.

  • performance-instance-store: My instance is experiencing performance problems that I believe are related to the instance stores.

  • performance-ebs-volume: My instance is experiencing performance problems that I believe are related to an EBS volume.

  • performance-other: My instance is experiencing performance problems.

  • other: [explain using the description parameter]

StartTime.documentation: The time at which the reported instance health state began.

Status.documentation: The status of all instances listed.

KernelId.documentation:
The ID of the kernel.

We recommend that you use PV-GRUB instead of kernels and RAM disks. For more information, see User Provided Kernels in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

EbsOptimized.documentation: Indicates whether the instance is optimized for Amazon EBS I/O. This optimization provides dedicated throughput to Amazon EBS and an optimized configuration stack to provide optimal Amazon EBS I/O performance. This optimization isn't available with all instance types. Additional usage charges apply when using an EBS-optimized instance.

BlockDeviceMappings.documentation:
The block device mapping.

Supplying both a snapshot ID and an encryption value as arguments for block-device mapping results in an error. This is because only blank volumes can be encrypted on start, and these are not created from a snapshot. If a snapshot is the basis for the volume, it contains data by definition and its encryption status cannot be changed using this action.

NetworkInterfaces.documentation: One or more network interfaces. If you specify a network interface, you must specify any security groups and subnets as part of the network interface.

InstanceType.documentation: The instance type. For more information, see Instance Types in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

KeyName.documentation:
The name of the key pair. You can create a key pair using CreateKeyPair or ImportKeyPair.

If you do not specify a key pair, you can't connect to the instance unless you choose an AMI that is configured to allow users another way to log in.

RamDiskId.documentation:
The ID of the RAM disk.

We recommend that you use PV-GRUB instead of kernels and RAM disks. For more information, see User Provided Kernels in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

DisableApiTermination.documentation: If you set this parameter to true, you can't terminate the instance using the Amazon EC2 console, CLI, or API; otherwise, you can. To change this attribute after launch, use ModifyInstanceAttribute. Alternatively, if you set InstanceInitiatedShutdownBehavior to terminate, you can terminate the instance by running the shutdown command from the instance.

InstanceInitiatedShutdownBehavior.documentation:
Indicates whether an instance stops or terminates when you initiate shutdown from the instance (using the operating system command for system shutdown).

Default: stop

UserData.documentation: The Base64-encoded user data to make available to the instance. For more information, see Running Commands on Your Linux Instance at Launch (Linux) and Adding User Data (Windows).

TagSpecifications.documentation: The tags to apply to the resources during launch. You can only tag instances and volumes on launch. The specified tags are applied to all instances or volumes that are created during launch. To tag a resource after it has been created, see CreateTags.

ElasticGpuSpecifications.documentation: An elastic GPU to associate with the instance.

ElasticInferenceAccelerators.documentation: The elastic inference accelerator for the instance.

SecurityGroupIds.documentation: One or more security group IDs. You can create a security group using CreateSecurityGroup. You cannot specify both a security group ID and security name in the same request.

SecurityGroups.documentation: [EC2-Classic, default VPC] One or more security group names. For a nondefault VPC, you must use security group IDs instead. You cannot specify both a security group ID and security name in the same request.

CreditSpecification.documentation: The credit option for CPU usage of the instance. Valid for T2 or T3 instances only.

CpuOptions.documentation: The CPU options for the instance. For more information, see Optimizing CPU Options in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

CapacityReservationSpecification.documentation: The Capacity Reservation targeting option. If you do not specify this parameter, the instance's Capacity Reservation preference defaults to open, which enables it to run in any open Capacity Reservation that has matching attributes (instance type, platform, Availability Zone).

HibernationOptions.documentation: Indicates whether an instance is enabled for hibernation. This parameter is valid only if the instance meets the hibernation prerequisites. Hibernation is currently supported only for Amazon Linux. For more information, see Hibernate Your Instance in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

RequestLaunchTemplateData.documentation: The information to include in the launch template.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

SpotFleetRequestConfig.documentation: The configuration for the Spot Fleet request.

SpotFleetRequestId.documentation: The ID of the Spot Fleet request.

AvailabilityZoneGroup.documentation:
The user-specified name for a logical grouping of requests.

When you specify an Availability Zone group in a Spot Instance request, all Spot Instances in the request are launched in the same Availability Zone. Instance proximity is maintained with this parameter, but the choice of Availability Zone is not. The group applies only to requests for Spot Instances of the same instance type. Any additional Spot Instance requests that are specified with the same Availability Zone group name are launched in that same Availability Zone, as long as at least one instance from the group is still active.

If there is no active instance running in the Availability Zone group that you specify for a new Spot Instance request (all instances are terminated, the request is expired, or the maximum price you specified falls below current Spot price), then Amazon EC2 launches the instance in any Availability Zone where the constraint can be met. Consequently, the subsequent set of Spot Instances could be placed in a different zone from the original request, even if you specified the same Availability Zone group.

Default: Instances are launched in any available Availability Zone.

BlockDurationMinutes.documentation:
The required duration for the Spot Instances (also known as Spot blocks), in minutes. This value must be a multiple of 60 (60, 120, 180, 240, 300, or 360).

The duration period starts as soon as your Spot Instance receives its instance ID. At the end of the duration period, Amazon EC2 marks the Spot Instance for termination and provides a Spot Instance termination notice, which gives the instance a two-minute warning before it terminates.

You can't specify an Availability Zone group or a launch group if you specify a duration.

ClientToken.documentation: Unique, case-sensitive identifier that you provide to ensure the idempotency of the request. For more information, see How to Ensure Idempotency in the Amazon EC2 User Guide for Linux Instances.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

InstanceCount.documentation:
The maximum number of Spot Instances to launch.

Default: 1

LaunchGroup.documentation:
The instance launch group. Launch groups are Spot Instances that launch together and terminate together.

Default: Instances are launched and terminated individually

SpotPrice.documentation: The maximum price per hour that you are willing to pay for a Spot Instance. The default is the On-Demand price.

Type.documentation:
The Spot Instance request type.

Default: one-time

ValidFrom.documentation:
The start date of the request. If this is a one-time request, the request becomes active at this date and time and remains active until all instances launch, the request expires, or the request is canceled. If the request is persistent, the request becomes active at this date and time and remains active until it expires or is canceled.

The specified start date and time cannot be equal to the current date and time. You must specify a start date and time that occurs after the current date and time.

ValidUntil.documentation: The end date of the request. If this is a one-time request, the request remains active until all instances launch, the request is canceled, or this date is reached. If the request is persistent, it remains active until it is canceled or this date is reached. The default end date is 7 days from the current date.

InstanceInterruptionBehavior.documentation: The behavior when a Spot Instance is interrupted. The default is terminate.

SecurityGroups.documentation: One or more security groups. When requesting instances in a VPC, you must specify the IDs of the security groups. When requesting instances in EC2-Classic, you can specify the names or the IDs of the security groups.

BlockDeviceMappings.documentation: One or more block device mapping entries. You can't specify both a snapshot ID and an encryption value. This is because only blank volumes can be encrypted on creation. If a snapshot is the basis for a volume, it is not blank and its encryption status is used for the volume encryption status.

EbsOptimized.documentation:
Indicates whether the instance is optimized for EBS I/O. This optimization provides dedicated throughput to Amazon EBS and an optimized configuration stack to provide optimal EBS I/O performance. This optimization isn't available with all instance types. Additional usage charges apply when using an EBS Optimized instance.

Default: false

InstanceType.documentation: The instance type.

Monitoring.documentation:
Indicates whether basic or detailed monitoring is enabled for the instance.

Default: Disabled

NetworkInterfaces.documentation: One or more network interfaces. If you specify a network interface, you must specify subnet IDs and security group IDs using the network interface.

SubnetId.documentation: The IDs of the subnets in which to launch the instance. To specify multiple subnets, separate them using commas; for example, "subnet-1234abcdeexample1, subnet-0987cdef6example2".

UserData.documentation: The Base64-encoded user data for the instance. User data is limited to 16 KB.

RequestSpotLaunchSpecification.documentation: Describes the launch specification for an instance.

OwnerId.documentation: The ID of the AWS account that owns the reservation.

RequesterId.documentation: The ID of the requester that launched the instances on your behalf (for example, AWS Management Console or Auto Scaling).

RemainingTotalValue.documentation: The balance of the total value (the sum of remainingUpfrontValue + hourlyPrice * number of hours remaining).

RemainingUpfrontValue.documentation: The remaining upfront cost of the reservation.

ReservationValue.documentation: The cost associated with the Reserved Instance.

Amount.documentation: Used for Reserved Instance Marketplace offerings. Specifies the limit price on the total order (instanceCount * price).

CurrencyCode.documentation: The currency in which the limitPrice amount is specified. At this time, the only supported currency is USD.

ReservedInstanceLimitPrice.documentation: Describes the limit price of a Reserved Instance offering.

ReservationValue.documentation: The total value of the Convertible Reserved Instance that you are exchanging.

ReservedInstanceId.documentation: The ID of the Convertible Reserved Instance that you are exchanging.

ReservedInstanceReservationValue.documentation: The total value of the Convertible Reserved Instance.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone in which the Reserved Instance can be used.

Duration.documentation: The duration of the Reserved Instance, in seconds.

End.documentation: The time when the Reserved Instance expires.

FixedPrice.documentation: The purchase price of the Reserved Instance.

InstanceType.documentation: The instance type on which the Reserved Instance can be used.

Start.documentation: The date and time the Reserved Instance started.

State.documentation: The state of the Reserved Instance purchase.

UsagePrice.documentation: The usage price of the Reserved Instance, per hour.

CurrencyCode.documentation: The currency of the Reserved Instance. It's specified using ISO 4217 standard currency codes. At this time, the only supported currency is USD.

OfferingClass.documentation: The offering class of the Reserved Instance.

RecurringCharges.documentation: The recurring charge tag assigned to the resource.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone for the modified Reserved Instances.

InstanceCount.documentation:
The number of modified Reserved Instances.

This is a required field for a request.

InstanceType.documentation: The instance type for the modified Reserved Instances.

Platform.documentation: The network platform of the modified Reserved Instances, which is either EC2-Classic or EC2-VPC.

Scope.documentation: Whether the Reserved Instance is applied to instances in a Region or instances in a specific Availability Zone.

ReservedInstancesConfiguration.documentation: Describes the configuration settings for the modified Reserved Instances.

ReservedInstancesId.documentation: Describes the ID of a Reserved Instance.

ClientToken.documentation: A unique, case-sensitive key supplied by the client to ensure that the request is idempotent. For more information, see Ensuring Idempotency.

InstanceCounts.documentation: The number of instances in this state.

PriceSchedules.documentation: The price of the Reserved Instance listing.

ReservedInstancesListingId.documentation: The ID of the Reserved Instance listing.

Status.documentation: The status of the Reserved Instance listing.

StatusMessage.documentation: The reason for the current status of the Reserved Instance listing. The response can be blank.

UpdateDate.documentation: The last modified timestamp of the listing.

ClientToken.documentation: A unique, case-sensitive key supplied by the client to ensure that the request is idempotent. For more information, see Ensuring Idempotency.

CreateDate.documentation: The time when the modification request was created.

EffectiveDate.documentation: The time for the modification to become effective.

ModificationResults.documentation: Contains target configurations along with their corresponding new Reserved Instance IDs.

ReservedInstancesIds.documentation: The IDs of one or more Reserved Instances.

ReservedInstancesModificationId.documentation: A unique ID for the Reserved Instance modification.

Status.documentation: The status of the Reserved Instances modification request.

UpdateDate.documentation: The time when the modification request was last updated.

ReservedInstancesId.documentation: The ID for the Reserved Instances that were created as part of the modification request. This field is only available when the modification is fulfilled.

TargetConfiguration.documentation: The target Reserved Instances configurations supplied as part of the modification request.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone in which the Reserved Instance can be used.

Duration.documentation: The duration of the Reserved Instance, in seconds.

FixedPrice.documentation: The purchase price of the Reserved Instance.

InstanceType.documentation: The instance type on which the Reserved Instance can be used.

ReservedInstancesOfferingId.documentation: The ID of the Reserved Instance offering. This is the offering ID used in GetReservedInstancesExchangeQuote to confirm that an exchange can be made.

UsagePrice.documentation: The usage price of the Reserved Instance, per hour.

CurrencyCode.documentation: The currency of the Reserved Instance offering you are purchasing. It's specified using ISO 4217 standard currency codes. At this time, the only supported currency is USD.

Marketplace.documentation: Indicates whether the offering is available through the Reserved Instance Marketplace (resale) or AWS. If it's a Reserved Instance Marketplace offering, this is true.

OfferingClass.documentation: If convertible it can be exchanged for Reserved Instances of the same or higher monetary value, with different configurations. If standard, it is not possible to perform an exchange.

PricingDetails.documentation: The pricing details of the Reserved Instance offering.

RecurringCharges.documentation: The recurring charge tag assigned to the resource.

Scope.documentation: Whether the Reserved Instance is applied to instances in a Region or an Availability Zone.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

KmsKeyId.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the default CMK for EBS encryption by default.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

Return.documentation: Is true if the request succeeds, and an error otherwise.

Attribute.documentation: The attribute to reset (currently you can only reset the launch permission attribute).

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

Attribute.documentation:
The attribute to reset.

You can only reset the following attributes: kernel | ramdisk | sourceDestCheck. To change an instance attribute, use ModifyInstanceAttribute.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

SourceDestCheck.documentation: The source/destination checking attribute. Resets the value to true.

Attribute.documentation: The attribute to reset. Currently, only the attribute for permission to create volumes can be reset.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

Code.documentation: The error code.

Message.documentation: The error message, if applicable.

ResponseError.documentation: Describes the error that's returned when you cannot delete a launch template version.

KernelId.documentation: The ID of the kernel, if applicable.

EbsOptimized.documentation: Indicates whether the instance is optimized for Amazon EBS I/O.

ImageId.documentation: The ID of the AMI that was used to launch the instance.

InstanceType.documentation: The instance type.

RamDiskId.documentation: The ID of the RAM disk, if applicable.

DisableApiTermination.documentation: If set to true, indicates that the instance cannot be terminated using the Amazon EC2 console, command line tool, or API.

InstanceInitiatedShutdownBehavior.documentation: Indicates whether an instance stops or terminates when you initiate shutdown from the instance (using the operating system command for system shutdown).

ElasticInferenceAccelerators.documentation: The elastic inference accelerator for the instance.

CreditSpecification.documentation: The credit option for CPU usage of the instance.

CpuOptions.documentation: The CPU options for the instance. For more information, see Optimizing CPU Options in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

CapacityReservationSpecification.documentation: Information about the Capacity Reservation targeting option.

HibernationOptions.documentation: Indicates whether an instance is configured for hibernation. For more information, see Hibernate Your Instance in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

Status.documentation: The move status for the IP address.

ClientVpnEndpointId.documentation: The ID of the Client VPN endpoint with which the authorization rule is associated.

TargetNetworkCidr.documentation: The IPv4 address range, in CIDR notation, of the network for which access is being removed.

AccessGroupId.documentation: The ID of the Active Directory group for which to revoke access.

RevokeAllGroups.documentation: Indicates whether access should be revoked for all clients.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

Status.documentation: The current state of the authorization rule.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

IpPermissions.documentation: The sets of IP permissions. You can't specify a destination security group and a CIDR IP address range in the same set of permissions.

CidrIp.documentation: Not supported. Use a set of IP permissions to specify the CIDR.

FromPort.documentation: Not supported. Use a set of IP permissions to specify the port.

IpProtocol.documentation: Not supported. Use a set of IP permissions to specify the protocol name or number.

ToPort.documentation: Not supported. Use a set of IP permissions to specify the port.

SourceSecurityGroupName.documentation: Not supported. Use a set of IP permissions to specify a destination security group.

SourceSecurityGroupOwnerId.documentation: Not supported. Use a set of IP permissions to specify a destination security group.

CidrIp.documentation: The CIDR IP address range. You can't specify this parameter when specifying a source security group.

FromPort.documentation: The start of port range for the TCP and UDP protocols, or an ICMP type number. For the ICMP type number, use -1 to specify all ICMP types.

GroupId.documentation: The ID of the security group. You must specify either the security group ID or the security group name in the request. For security groups in a nondefault VPC, you must specify the security group ID.

GroupName.documentation: [EC2-Classic, default VPC] The name of the security group. You must specify either the security group ID or the security group name in the request.

IpPermissions.documentation: The sets of IP permissions. You can't specify a source security group and a CIDR IP address range in the same set of permissions.

IpProtocol.documentation: The IP protocol name (tcp, udp, icmp) or number (see Protocol Numbers). Use -1 to specify all.

SourceSecurityGroupName.documentation: [EC2-Classic, default VPC] The name of the source security group. You can't specify this parameter in combination with the following parameters: the CIDR IP address range, the start of the port range, the IP protocol, and the end of the port range. For EC2-VPC, the source security group must be in the same VPC. To revoke a specific rule for an IP protocol and port range, use a set of IP permissions instead.

SourceSecurityGroupOwnerId.documentation: [EC2-Classic] The AWS account ID of the source security group, if the source security group is in a different account. You can't specify this parameter in combination with the following parameters: the CIDR IP address range, the IP protocol, the start of the port range, and the end of the port range. To revoke a specific rule for an IP protocol and port range, use a set of IP permissions instead.

ToPort.documentation: The end of port range for the TCP and UDP protocols, or an ICMP code number. For the ICMP code number, use -1 to specify all ICMP codes for the ICMP type.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

DestinationCidrBlock.documentation: The IPv4 CIDR block used for the destination match.

DestinationIpv6CidrBlock.documentation: The IPv6 CIDR block used for the destination match.

EgressOnlyInternetGatewayId.documentation: The ID of the egress-only internet gateway.

GatewayId.documentation: The ID of a gateway attached to your VPC.

InstanceId.documentation: The ID of a NAT instance in your VPC.

InstanceOwnerId.documentation: The AWS account ID of the owner of the instance.

Origin.documentation:
Describes how the route was created.

  • CreateRouteTable - The route was automatically created when the route table was created.

  • CreateRoute - The route was manually added to the route table.

  • EnableVgwRoutePropagation - The route was propagated by route propagation.

State.documentation: The state of the route. The blackhole state indicates that the route's target isn't available (for example, the specified gateway isn't attached to the VPC, or the specified NAT instance has been terminated).

VpcPeeringConnectionId.documentation: The ID of a VPC peering connection.

Route.documentation: Describes a route in a route table.

Associations.documentation: The associations between the route table and one or more subnets.

Tags.documentation: Any tags assigned to the route table.

OwnerId.documentation: The ID of the AWS account that owns the route table.

Main.documentation: Indicates whether this is the main route table.

RouteTableAssociationId.documentation: The ID of the association between a route table and a subnet.

SubnetId.documentation: The ID of the subnet. A subnet ID is not returned for an implicit association.

RouteTableAssociation.documentation: Describes an association between a route table and a subnet.

Enabled.documentation: Indicates whether detailed monitoring is enabled. Otherwise, basic monitoring is enabled.

ImageId.documentation: The ID of the AMI. An AMI ID is required to launch an instance and must be specified here or in a launch template.

InstanceType.documentation:
The instance type. For more information, see Instance Types in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

Default: m1.small

Ipv6AddressCount.documentation:
[EC2-VPC] The number of IPv6 addresses to associate with the primary network interface. Amazon EC2 chooses the IPv6 addresses from the range of your subnet. You cannot specify this option and the option to assign specific IPv6 addresses in the same request. You can specify this option if you've specified a minimum number of instances to launch.

You cannot specify this option and the network interfaces option in the same request.

Ipv6Addresses.documentation:
[EC2-VPC] The IPv6 addresses from the range of the subnet to associate with the primary network interface. You cannot specify this option and the option to assign a number of IPv6 addresses in the same request. You cannot specify this option if you've specified a minimum number of instances to launch.

You cannot specify this option and the network interfaces option in the same request.

KernelId.documentation:
The ID of the kernel.

We recommend that you use PV-GRUB instead of kernels and RAM disks. For more information, see PV-GRUB in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

KeyName.documentation:
The name of the key pair. You can create a key pair using CreateKeyPair or ImportKeyPair.

If you do not specify a key pair, you can't connect to the instance unless you choose an AMI that is configured to allow users another way to log in.

MaxCount.documentation:
The maximum number of instances to launch. If you specify more instances than Amazon EC2 can launch in the target Availability Zone, Amazon EC2 launches the largest possible number of instances above MinCount.

Constraints: Between 1 and the maximum number you're allowed for the specified instance type. For more information about the default limits, and how to request an increase, see How many instances can I run in Amazon EC2 in the Amazon EC2 FAQ.

MinCount.documentation:
The minimum number of instances to launch. If you specify a minimum that is more instances than Amazon EC2 can launch in the target Availability Zone, Amazon EC2 launches no instances.

Constraints: Between 1 and the maximum number you're allowed for the specified instance type. For more information about the default limits, and how to request an increase, see How many instances can I run in Amazon EC2 in the Amazon EC2 General FAQ.

Monitoring.documentation: Specifies whether detailed monitoring is enabled for the instance.

RamdiskId.documentation:
The ID of the RAM disk to select. Some kernels require additional drivers at launch. Check the kernel requirements for information about whether you need to specify a RAM disk. To find kernel requirements, go to the AWS Resource Center and search for the kernel ID.

We recommend that you use PV-GRUB instead of kernels and RAM disks. For more information, see PV-GRUB in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

SecurityGroupIds.documentation:
The IDs of the security groups. You can create a security group using CreateSecurityGroup.

If you specify a network interface, you must specify any security groups as part of the network interface.

SecurityGroups.documentation:
[EC2-Classic, default VPC] The names of the security groups. For a nondefault VPC, you must use security group IDs instead.

If you specify a network interface, you must specify any security groups as part of the network interface.

Default: Amazon EC2 uses the default security group.

SubnetId.documentation:
[EC2-VPC] The ID of the subnet to launch the instance into.

If you specify a network interface, you must specify any subnets as part of the network interface.

UserData.documentation: The user data to make available to the instance. For more information, see Running Commands on Your Linux Instance at Launch (Linux) and Adding User Data (Windows). If you are using a command line tool, base64-encoding is performed for you, and you can load the text from a file. Otherwise, you must provide base64-encoded text. User data is limited to 16 KB.

ClientToken.documentation:
Unique, case-sensitive identifier you provide to ensure the idempotency of the request. For more information, see Ensuring Idempotency.

Constraints: Maximum 64 ASCII characters

DisableApiTermination.documentation:
If you set this parameter to true, you can't terminate the instance using the Amazon EC2 console, CLI, or API; otherwise, you can. To change this attribute after launch, use ModifyInstanceAttribute. Alternatively, if you set InstanceInitiatedShutdownBehavior to terminate, you can terminate the instance by running the shutdown command from the instance.

Default: false

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

EbsOptimized.documentation:
Indicates whether the instance is optimized for Amazon EBS I/O. This optimization provides dedicated throughput to Amazon EBS and an optimized configuration stack to provide optimal Amazon EBS I/O performance. This optimization isn't available with all instance types. Additional usage charges apply when using an EBS-optimized instance.

Default: false

InstanceInitiatedShutdownBehavior.documentation:
Indicates whether an instance stops or terminates when you initiate shutdown from the instance (using the operating system command for system shutdown).

Default: stop

NetworkInterfaces.documentation: The network interfaces to associate with the instance. If you specify a network interface, you must specify any security groups and subnets as part of the network interface.

PrivateIpAddress.documentation:
[EC2-VPC] The primary IPv4 address. You must specify a value from the IPv4 address range of the subnet.

Only one private IP address can be designated as primary. You can't specify this option if you've specified the option to designate a private IP address as the primary IP address in a network interface specification. You cannot specify this option if you're launching more than one instance in the request.

You cannot specify this option and the network interfaces option in the same request.

ElasticGpuSpecification.documentation: An elastic GPU to associate with the instance. An Elastic GPU is a GPU resource that you can attach to your Windows instance to accelerate the graphics performance of your applications. For more information, see Amazon EC2 Elastic GPUs in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

ElasticInferenceAccelerators.documentation: An elastic inference accelerator to associate with the instance. Elastic inference accelerators are a resource you can attach to your Amazon EC2 instances to accelerate your Deep Learning (DL) inference workloads.

TagSpecifications.documentation: The tags to apply to the resources during launch. You can only tag instances and volumes on launch. The specified tags are applied to all instances or volumes that are created during launch. To tag a resource after it has been created, see CreateTags.

LaunchTemplate.documentation: The launch template to use to launch the instances. Any parameters that you specify in RunInstances override the same parameters in the launch template. You can specify either the name or ID of a launch template, but not both.

InstanceMarketOptions.documentation:
The market (purchasing) option for the instances.

For RunInstances, persistent Spot Instance requests are only supported when InstanceInterruptionBehavior is set to either hibernate or stop.

CreditSpecification.documentation:
The credit option for CPU usage of the T2 or T3 instance. Valid values are standard and unlimited. To change this attribute after launch, use ModifyInstanceCreditSpecification. For more information, see Burstable Performance Instances in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

Default: standard (T2 instances) or unlimited (T3 instances)

CpuOptions.documentation: The CPU options for the instance. For more information, see Optimizing CPU Options in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

CapacityReservationSpecification.documentation: Information about the Capacity Reservation targeting option. If you do not specify this parameter, the instance's Capacity Reservation preference defaults to open, which enables it to run in any open Capacity Reservation that has matching attributes (instance type, platform, Availability Zone).

HibernationOptions.documentation: Indicates whether an instance is enabled for hibernation. For more information, see Hibernate Your Instance in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

ClientToken.documentation: Unique, case-sensitive identifier that ensures the idempotency of the request. For more information, see Ensuring Idempotency.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

LaunchSpecification.documentation: The launch specification. You must match the instance type, Availability Zone, network, and platform of the schedule that you purchased.

InstanceIdSet.documentation: The IDs of the newly launched instances.

AWSAccessKeyId.documentation: The access key ID of the owner of the bucket. Before you specify a value for your access key ID, review and follow the guidance in Best Practices for Managing AWS Access Keys.

Bucket.documentation: The bucket in which to store the AMI. You can specify a bucket that you already own or a new bucket that Amazon EC2 creates on your behalf. If you specify a bucket that belongs to someone else, Amazon EC2 returns an error.

Prefix.documentation: The beginning of the file name of the AMI.

UploadPolicy.documentation: An Amazon S3 upload policy that gives Amazon EC2 permission to upload items into Amazon S3 on your behalf.

S3Storage.documentation: Describes the storage parameters for S3 and S3 buckets for an instance store-backed AMI.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone.

CreateDate.documentation: The date when the Scheduled Instance was purchased.

HourlyPrice.documentation: The hourly price for a single instance.

InstanceType.documentation: The instance type.

NextSlotStartTime.documentation: The time for the next schedule to start.

PreviousSlotEndTime.documentation: The time that the previous schedule ended or will end.

SlotDurationInHours.documentation: The number of hours in the schedule.

TermEndDate.documentation: The end date for the Scheduled Instance.

TermStartDate.documentation: The start date for the Scheduled Instance.

TotalScheduledInstanceHours.documentation: The total number of hours for a single instance for the entire term.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone.

FirstSlotStartTime.documentation: The time period for the first schedule to start.

HourlyPrice.documentation: The hourly price for a single instance.

InstanceType.documentation: The instance type. You can specify one of the C3, C4, M4, or R3 instance types.

MaxTermDurationInDays.documentation: The maximum term. The only possible value is 365 days.

MinTermDurationInDays.documentation: The minimum term. The only possible value is 365 days.

PurchaseToken.documentation: The purchase token. This token expires in two hours.

SlotDurationInHours.documentation: The number of hours in the schedule.

TotalScheduledInstanceHours.documentation: The total number of hours for a single instance for the entire term.

ScheduledInstanceAvailability.documentation: Describes a schedule that is available for your Scheduled Instances.

Interval.documentation: The interval quantity. The interval unit depends on the value of frequency. For example, every 2 weeks or every 2 months.

OccurrenceDaySet.documentation: The days. For a monthly schedule, this is one or more days of the month (1-31). For a weekly schedule, this is one or more days of the week (1-7, where 1 is Sunday).

OccurrenceRelativeToEnd.documentation: Indicates whether the occurrence is relative to the end of the specified week or month.

ScheduledInstanceRecurrence.documentation: Describes the recurring schedule for a Scheduled Instance.

Interval.documentation: The interval quantity. The interval unit depends on the value of Frequency. For example, every 2 weeks or every 2 months.

OccurrenceDays.documentation: The days. For a monthly schedule, this is one or more days of the month (1-31). For a weekly schedule, this is one or more days of the week (1-7, where 1 is Sunday). You can't specify this value with a daily schedule. If the occurrence is relative to the end of the month, you can specify only a single day.

OccurrenceRelativeToEnd.documentation: Indicates whether the occurrence is relative to the end of the specified week or month. You can't specify this value with a daily schedule.

OccurrenceUnit.documentation: The unit for OccurrenceDays (DayOfWeek or DayOfMonth). This value is required for a monthly schedule. You can't specify DayOfWeek with a weekly schedule. You can't specify this value with a daily schedule.

ScheduledInstanceRecurrenceRequest.documentation: Describes the recurring schedule for a Scheduled Instance.

Ebs.documentation: Parameters used to set up EBS volumes automatically when the instance is launched.

NoDevice.documentation: Suppresses the specified device included in the block device mapping of the AMI.

VirtualName.documentation:
The virtual device name (ephemeralN). Instance store volumes are numbered starting from 0. An instance type with two available instance store volumes can specify mappings for ephemeral0 and ephemeral1. The number of available instance store volumes depends on the instance type. After you connect to the instance, you must mount the volume.

Constraints: For M3 instances, you must specify instance store volumes in the block device mapping for the instance. When you launch an M3 instance, we ignore any instance store volumes specified in the block device mapping for the AMI.

ScheduledInstancesBlockDeviceMapping.documentation: Describes a block device mapping for a Scheduled Instance.

DeleteOnTermination.documentation: Indicates whether the volume is deleted on instance termination.

Encrypted.documentation: Indicates whether the volume is encrypted. You can attached encrypted volumes only to instances that support them.

Iops.documentation:
The number of I/O operations per second (IOPS) that the volume supports. For io1 volumes, this represents the number of IOPS that are provisioned for the volume. For gp2 volumes, this represents the baseline performance of the volume and the rate at which the volume accumulates I/O credits for bursting. For more information about gp2 baseline performance, I/O credits, and bursting, see Amazon EBS Volume Types in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

Constraint: Range is 100-20000 IOPS for io1 volumes and 100-10000 IOPS for gp2 volumes.

Condition: This parameter is required for requests to create io1volumes; it is not used in requests to create gp2, st1, sc1, or standard volumes.

VolumeSize.documentation:
The size of the volume, in GiB.

Default: If you're creating the volume from a snapshot and don't specify a volume size, the default is the snapshot size.

VolumeType.documentation:
The volume type. gp2 for General Purpose SSD, io1 for Provisioned IOPS SSD, Throughput Optimized HDD for st1, Cold HDD for sc1, or standard for Magnetic.

Default: gp2

ScheduledInstancesEbs.documentation: Describes an EBS volume for a Scheduled Instance.

ScheduledInstancesIamInstanceProfile.documentation: Describes an IAM instance profile for a Scheduled Instance.

EbsOptimized.documentation:
Indicates whether the instances are optimized for EBS I/O. This optimization provides dedicated throughput to Amazon EBS and an optimized configuration stack to provide optimal EBS I/O performance. This optimization isn't available with all instance types. Additional usage charges apply when using an EBS-optimized instance.

Default: false

ImageId.documentation: The ID of the Amazon Machine Image (AMI).

InstanceType.documentation: The instance type.

Monitoring.documentation: Enable or disable monitoring for the instances.

SubnetId.documentation: The ID of the subnet in which to launch the instances.

ScheduledInstancesLaunchSpecification.documentation:
Describes the launch specification for a Scheduled Instance.

If you are launching the Scheduled Instance in EC2-VPC, you must specify the ID of the subnet. You can specify the subnet using either SubnetId or NetworkInterface.

ScheduledInstancesMonitoring.documentation: Describes whether monitoring is enabled for a Scheduled Instance.

AssociatePublicIpAddress.documentation: Indicates whether to assign a public IPv4 address to instances launched in a VPC. The public IPv4 address can only be assigned to a network interface for eth0, and can only be assigned to a new network interface, not an existing one. You cannot specify more than one network interface in the request. If launching into a default subnet, the default value is true.

DeleteOnTermination.documentation: Indicates whether to delete the interface when the instance is terminated.

DeviceIndex.documentation: The index of the device for the network interface attachment.

Ipv6AddressCount.documentation: The number of IPv6 addresses to assign to the network interface. The IPv6 addresses are automatically selected from the subnet range.

Ipv6Addresses.documentation: The specific IPv6 addresses from the subnet range.

PrivateIpAddress.documentation: The IPv4 address of the network interface within the subnet.

SecondaryPrivateIpAddressCount.documentation: The number of secondary private IPv4 addresses.

SubnetId.documentation: The ID of the subnet.

ScheduledInstancesNetworkInterface.documentation: Describes a network interface for a Scheduled Instance.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone.

GroupName.documentation: The name of the placement group.

ScheduledInstancesPlacement.documentation: Describes the placement for a Scheduled Instance.

Primary.documentation: Indicates whether this is a primary IPv4 address. Otherwise, this is a secondary IPv4 address.

ScheduledInstancesPrivateIpAddressConfig.documentation: Describes a private IPv4 address for a Scheduled Instance.

TransitGatewayRouteTableId.documentation: The ID of the transit gateway route table.

Filters.documentation:
One or more filters. The possible values are:

  • attachment.transit-gateway-attachment-id- The id of the transit gateway attachment.

  • attachment.resource-id - The resource id of the transit gateway attachment.

  • attachment.resource-type - The attachment resource type (vpc | vpn).

  • route-search.exact-match - The exact match of the specified filter.

  • route-search.longest-prefix-match - The longest prefix that matches the route.

  • route-search.subnet-of-match - The routes with a subnet that match the specified CIDR filter.

  • route-search.supernet-of-match - The routes with a CIDR that encompass the CIDR filter. For example, if you have 10.0.1.0/29 and 10.0.1.0/31 routes in your route table and you specify supernet-of-match as 10.0.1.0/30, then the result returns 10.0.1.0/29.

  • state - The state of the route (active | blackhole).

  • type - The type of route (propagated | static).

MaxResults.documentation: The maximum number of routes to return.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

AdditionalRoutesAvailable.documentation: Indicates whether there are additional routes available.

GroupName.documentation: The name of the security group.

IpPermissions.documentation: The inbound rules associated with the security group.

OwnerId.documentation: The AWS account ID of the owner of the security group.

IpPermissionsEgress.documentation: [VPC only] The outbound rules associated with the security group.

Tags.documentation: Any tags assigned to the security group.

VpcId.documentation: [VPC only] The ID of the VPC for the security group.

GroupName.documentation: The name of the security group.

ReferencingVpcId.documentation: The ID of the VPC with the referencing security group.

VpcPeeringConnectionId.documentation: The ID of the VPC peering connection.

SecurityGroupReference.documentation: Describes a VPC with a security group that references your security group.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

AvailabilityZones.documentation: In the Availability Zones in which the service is available.

AcceptanceRequired.documentation: Indicates whether requests from other AWS accounts to create an endpoint to the service must first be accepted.

ManagesVpcEndpoints.documentation: Indicates whether the service manages it's VPC endpoints. Management of the service VPC endpoints using the VPC endpoint API is restricted.

NetworkLoadBalancerArns.documentation: The Amazon Resource Names (ARNs) of the Network Load Balancers for the service.

PrivateDnsName.documentation: The private DNS name for the service.

ServiceConfiguration.documentation: Describes a service configuration for a VPC endpoint service.

ServiceName.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the service.

AvailabilityZones.documentation: The Availability Zones in which the service is available.

Owner.documentation: The AWS account ID of the service owner.

PrivateDnsName.documentation: The private DNS name for the service.

VpcEndpointPolicySupported.documentation: Indicates whether the service supports endpoint policies.

AcceptanceRequired.documentation: Indicates whether VPC endpoint connection requests to the service must be accepted by the service owner.

ManagesVpcEndpoints.documentation: Indicates whether the service manages it's VPC endpoints. Management of the service VPC endpoints using the VPC endpoint API is restricted.

ServiceTypeDetail.documentation: Describes the type of service for a VPC endpoint.

EarliestTime.documentation: The earliest date and time, in UTC, for the Scheduled Instance to start.

LatestTime.documentation: The latest date and time, in UTC, for the Scheduled Instance to start. This value must be later than or equal to the earliest date and at most three months in the future.

SlotDateTimeRangeRequest.documentation: Describes the time period for a Scheduled Instance to start its first schedule. The time period must span less than one day.

EarliestTime.documentation: The earliest date and time, in UTC, for the Scheduled Instance to start.

LatestTime.documentation: The latest date and time, in UTC, for the Scheduled Instance to start.

SlotStartTimeRangeRequest.documentation: Describes the time period for a Scheduled Instance to start its first schedule.

DataEncryptionKeyId.documentation: The data encryption key identifier for the snapshot. This value is a unique identifier that corresponds to the data encryption key that was used to encrypt the original volume or snapshot copy. Because data encryption keys are inherited by volumes created from snapshots, and vice versa, if snapshots share the same data encryption key identifier, then they belong to the same volume/snapshot lineage. This parameter is only returned by DescribeSnapshots.

KmsKeyId.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) customer master key (CMK) that was used to protect the volume encryption key for the parent volume.

OwnerId.documentation: The AWS account ID of the EBS snapshot owner.

Progress.documentation: The progress of the snapshot, as a percentage.

SnapshotId.documentation: The ID of the snapshot. Each snapshot receives a unique identifier when it is created.

StartTime.documentation: The time stamp when the snapshot was initiated.

StateMessage.documentation: Encrypted Amazon EBS snapshots are copied asynchronously. If a snapshot copy operation fails (for example, if the proper AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) permissions are not obtained) this field displays error state details to help you diagnose why the error occurred. This parameter is only returned by DescribeSnapshots.

VolumeId.documentation: The ID of the volume that was used to create the snapshot. Snapshots created by the CopySnapshot action have an arbitrary volume ID that should not be used for any purpose.

VolumeSize.documentation: The size of the volume, in GiB.

OwnerAlias.documentation: Value from an Amazon-maintained list (amazon | self | all | aws-marketplace | microsoft) of snapshot owners. Not to be confused with the user-configured AWS account alias, which is set from the IAM console.

DeviceName.documentation: The block device mapping for the snapshot.

DiskImageSize.documentation: The size of the disk in the snapshot, in GiB.

Format.documentation: The format of the disk image from which the snapshot is created.

Progress.documentation: The percentage of progress for the task.

SnapshotId.documentation: The snapshot ID of the disk being imported.

Status.documentation: A brief status of the snapshot creation.

StatusMessage.documentation: A detailed status message for the snapshot creation.

Url.documentation: The URL used to access the disk image.

UserBucket.documentation: The S3 bucket for the disk image.

SnapshotDetail.documentation: Describes the snapshot created from the imported disk.

Description.documentation: The description of the disk image being imported.

Format.documentation:
The format of the disk image being imported.

Valid values: VHD | VMDK

Url.documentation: The URL to the Amazon S3-based disk image being imported. It can either be a https URL (https://..) or an Amazon S3 URL (s3://..).

UserBucket.documentation: The S3 bucket for the disk image.

SnapshotDiskContainer.documentation: The disk container object for the import snapshot request.

Description.documentation: Description specified by the CreateSnapshotRequest that has been applied to all snapshots.

VolumeId.documentation: Source volume from which this snapshot was created.

VolumeSize.documentation: Size of the volume from which this snapshot was created.

StartTime.documentation: Time this snapshot was started. This is the same for all snapshots initiated by the same request.

Progress.documentation: Progress this snapshot has made towards completing.

OwnerId.documentation: Account id used when creating this snapshot.

SnapshotId.documentation: Snapshot id that can be used to describe this snapshot.

DiskImageSize.documentation: The size of the disk in the snapshot, in GiB.

Format.documentation: The format of the disk image from which the snapshot is created.

KmsKeyId.documentation: The identifier for the AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) customer master key (CMK) that was used to create the encrypted snapshot.

Progress.documentation: The percentage of completion for the import snapshot task.

SnapshotId.documentation: The snapshot ID of the disk being imported.

Status.documentation: A brief status for the import snapshot task.

StatusMessage.documentation: A detailed status message for the import snapshot task.

Url.documentation: The URL of the disk image from which the snapshot is created.

UserBucket.documentation: The S3 bucket for the disk image.

Bucket.documentation: The Amazon S3 bucket where the Spot Instance data feed is located.

Fault.documentation: The fault codes for the Spot Instance request, if any.

OwnerId.documentation: The AWS account ID of the account.

Prefix.documentation: The prefix that is prepended to data feed files.

State.documentation: The state of the Spot Instance data feed subscription.

SpotDatafeedSubscription.documentation: Describes the data feed for a Spot Instance.

SecurityGroups.documentation: One or more security groups. When requesting instances in a VPC, you must specify the IDs of the security groups. When requesting instances in EC2-Classic, you can specify the names or the IDs of the security groups.

BlockDeviceMappings.documentation: One or more block devices that are mapped to the Spot Instances. You can't specify both a snapshot ID and an encryption value. This is because only blank volumes can be encrypted on creation. If a snapshot is the basis for a volume, it is not blank and its encryption status is used for the volume encryption status.

EbsOptimized.documentation:
Indicates whether the instances are optimized for EBS I/O. This optimization provides dedicated throughput to Amazon EBS and an optimized configuration stack to provide optimal EBS I/O performance. This optimization isn't available with all instance types. Additional usage charges apply when using an EBS Optimized instance.

Default: false

InstanceType.documentation: The instance type.

Monitoring.documentation: Enable or disable monitoring for the instances.

NetworkInterfaces.documentation: One or more network interfaces. If you specify a network interface, you must specify subnet IDs and security group IDs using the network interface.

RamdiskId.documentation: The ID of the RAM disk. Some kernels require additional drivers at launch. Check the kernel requirements for information about whether you need to specify a RAM disk. To find kernel requirements, refer to the AWS Resource Center and search for the kernel ID.

SpotPrice.documentation: The maximum price per unit hour that you are willing to pay for a Spot Instance. If this value is not specified, the default is the Spot price specified for the fleet. To determine the Spot price per unit hour, divide the Spot price by the value of WeightedCapacity.

SubnetId.documentation: The IDs of the subnets in which to launch the instances. To specify multiple subnets, separate them using commas; for example, "subnet-1234abcdeexample1, subnet-0987cdef6example2".

UserData.documentation: The Base64-encoded user data that instances use when starting up.

WeightedCapacity.documentation:
The number of units provided by the specified instance type. These are the same units that you chose to set the target capacity in terms of instances, or a performance characteristic such as vCPUs, memory, or I/O.

If the target capacity divided by this value is not a whole number, Amazon EC2 rounds the number of instances to the next whole number. If this value is not specified, the default is 1.

SpotFleetLaunchSpecification.documentation: Describes the launch specification for one or more Spot Instances. If you include On-Demand capacity in your fleet request, you can't use SpotFleetLaunchSpecification; you must use LaunchTemplateConfig.

ActivityStatus.documentation: The progress of the Spot Fleet request. If there is an error, the status is error. After all requests are placed, the status is pending_fulfillment. If the size of the fleet is equal to or greater than its target capacity, the status is fulfilled. If the size of the fleet is decreased, the status is pending_termination while Spot Instances are terminating.

CreateTime.documentation: The creation date and time of the request.

SpotFleetRequestConfig.documentation: The configuration of the Spot Fleet request.

SpotFleetRequestId.documentation: The ID of the Spot Fleet request.

SpotFleetRequestState.documentation: The state of the Spot Fleet request.

AllocationStrategy.documentation:
Indicates how to allocate the target Spot Instance capacity across the Spot Instance pools specified by the Spot Fleet request.

If the allocation strategy is lowestPrice, Spot Fleet launches instances from the Spot Instance pools with the lowest price. This is the default allocation strategy.

If the allocation strategy is diversified, Spot Fleet launches instances from all the Spot Instance pools that you specify.

If the allocation strategy is capacityOptimized, Spot Fleet launches instances from Spot Instance pools with optimal capacity for the number of instances that are launching.

OnDemandAllocationStrategy.documentation: The order of the launch template overrides to use in fulfilling On-Demand capacity. If you specify lowestPrice, Spot Fleet uses price to determine the order, launching the lowest price first. If you specify prioritized, Spot Fleet uses the priority that you assign to each Spot Fleet launch template override, launching the highest priority first. If you do not specify a value, Spot Fleet defaults to lowestPrice.

ClientToken.documentation: A unique, case-sensitive identifier that you provide to ensure the idempotency of your listings. This helps to avoid duplicate listings. For more information, see Ensuring Idempotency.

ExcessCapacityTerminationPolicy.documentation: Indicates whether running Spot Instances should be terminated if you decrease the target capacity of the Spot Fleet request below the current size of the Spot Fleet.

FulfilledCapacity.documentation: The number of units fulfilled by this request compared to the set target capacity. You cannot set this value.

OnDemandFulfilledCapacity.documentation: The number of On-Demand units fulfilled by this request compared to the set target On-Demand capacity.

IamFleetRole.documentation: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of an AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) role that grants the Spot Fleet the permission to request, launch, terminate, and tag instances on your behalf. For more information, see Spot Fleet Prerequisites in the Amazon EC2 User Guide for Linux Instances. Spot Fleet can terminate Spot Instances on your behalf when you cancel its Spot Fleet request using CancelSpotFleetRequests or when the Spot Fleet request expires, if you set TerminateInstancesWithExpiration.

LaunchSpecifications.documentation: The launch specifications for the Spot Fleet request. If you specify LaunchSpecifications, you can't specify LaunchTemplateConfigs. If you include On-Demand capacity in your request, you must use LaunchTemplateConfigs.

LaunchTemplateConfigs.documentation: The launch template and overrides. If you specify LaunchTemplateConfigs, you can't specify LaunchSpecifications. If you include On-Demand capacity in your request, you must use LaunchTemplateConfigs.

SpotPrice.documentation: The maximum price per unit hour that you are willing to pay for a Spot Instance. The default is the On-Demand price.

TargetCapacity.documentation: The number of units to request for the Spot Fleet. You can choose to set the target capacity in terms of instances or a performance characteristic that is important to your application workload, such as vCPUs, memory, or I/O. If the request type is maintain, you can specify a target capacity of 0 and add capacity later.

OnDemandTargetCapacity.documentation: The number of On-Demand units to request. You can choose to set the target capacity in terms of instances or a performance characteristic that is important to your application workload, such as vCPUs, memory, or I/O. If the request type is maintain, you can specify a target capacity of 0 and add capacity later.

OnDemandMaxTotalPrice.documentation: The maximum amount per hour for On-Demand Instances that you're willing to pay. You can use the onDemandMaxTotalPrice parameter, the spotMaxTotalPrice parameter, or both parameters to ensure that your fleet cost does not exceed your budget. If you set a maximum price per hour for the On-Demand Instances and Spot Instances in your request, Spot Fleet will launch instances until it reaches the maximum amount you're willing to pay. When the maximum amount you're willing to pay is reached, the fleet stops launching instances even if it hasn’t met the target capacity.

SpotMaxTotalPrice.documentation: The maximum amount per hour for Spot Instances that you're willing to pay. You can use the spotdMaxTotalPrice parameter, the onDemandMaxTotalPrice parameter, or both parameters to ensure that your fleet cost does not exceed your budget. If you set a maximum price per hour for the On-Demand Instances and Spot Instances in your request, Spot Fleet will launch instances until it reaches the maximum amount you're willing to pay. When the maximum amount you're willing to pay is reached, the fleet stops launching instances even if it hasn’t met the target capacity.

TerminateInstancesWithExpiration.documentation: Indicates whether running Spot Instances are terminated when the Spot Fleet request expires.

Type.documentation: The type of request. Indicates whether the Spot Fleet only requests the target capacity or also attempts to maintain it. When this value is request, the Spot Fleet only places the required requests. It does not attempt to replenish Spot Instances if capacity is diminished, nor does it submit requests in alternative Spot pools if capacity is not available. When this value is maintain, the Spot Fleet maintains the target capacity. The Spot Fleet places the required requests to meet capacity and automatically replenishes any interrupted instances. Default: maintain. instant is listed but is not used by Spot Fleet.

ValidFrom.documentation: The start date and time of the request, in UTC format (YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ). By default, Amazon EC2 starts fulfilling the request immediately.

ValidUntil.documentation: The end date and time of the request, in UTC format (YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ). After the end date and time, no new Spot Instance requests are placed or able to fulfill the request. If no value is specified, the Spot Fleet request remains until you cancel it.

ReplaceUnhealthyInstances.documentation: Indicates whether Spot Fleet should replace unhealthy instances.

InstanceInterruptionBehavior.documentation: The behavior when a Spot Instance is interrupted. The default is terminate.

LoadBalancersConfig.documentation:
One or more Classic Load Balancers and target groups to attach to the Spot Fleet request. Spot Fleet registers the running Spot Instances with the specified Classic Load Balancers and target groups.

With Network Load Balancers, Spot Fleet cannot register instances that have the following instance types: C1, CC1, CC2, CG1, CG2, CR1, CS1, G1, G2, HI1, HS1, M1, M2, M3, and T1.

InstancePoolsToUseCount.documentation: The number of Spot pools across which to allocate your target Spot capacity. Valid only when Spot AllocationStrategy is set to lowest-price. Spot Fleet selects the cheapest Spot pools and evenly allocates your target Spot capacity across the number of Spot pools that you specify.

SpotFleetRequestConfigData.documentation: Describes the configuration of a Spot Fleet request.

ResourceType.documentation: The type of resource. Currently, the only resource type that is supported is instance.

SpotFleetTagSpecification.documentation: The tags for a Spot Fleet resource.

ActualBlockHourlyPrice.documentation: If you specified a duration and your Spot Instance request was fulfilled, this is the fixed hourly price in effect for the Spot Instance while it runs.

AvailabilityZoneGroup.documentation: The Availability Zone group. If you specify the same Availability Zone group for all Spot Instance requests, all Spot Instances are launched in the same Availability Zone.

BlockDurationMinutes.documentation: The duration for the Spot Instance, in minutes.

CreateTime.documentation: The date and time when the Spot Instance request was created, in UTC format (for example, YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ).

Fault.documentation: The fault codes for the Spot Instance request, if any.

InstanceId.documentation: The instance ID, if an instance has been launched to fulfill the Spot Instance request.

LaunchGroup.documentation: The instance launch group. Launch groups are Spot Instances that launch together and terminate together.

LaunchedAvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone in which the request is launched.

ProductDescription.documentation: The product description associated with the Spot Instance.

SpotInstanceRequestId.documentation: The ID of the Spot Instance request.

SpotPrice.documentation: The maximum price per hour that you are willing to pay for a Spot Instance.

State.documentation: The state of the Spot Instance request. Spot status information helps track your Spot Instance requests. For more information, see Spot Status in the Amazon EC2 User Guide for Linux Instances.

Status.documentation: The status code and status message describing the Spot Instance request.

Type.documentation: The Spot Instance request type.

ValidFrom.documentation: The start date of the request, in UTC format (for example, YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ). The request becomes active at this date and time.

ValidUntil.documentation: The end date of the request, in UTC format (for example, YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ). If this is a one-time request, it remains active until all instances launch, the request is canceled, or this date is reached. If the request is persistent, it remains active until it is canceled or this date is reached. The default end date is 7 days from the current date.

InstanceInterruptionBehavior.documentation: The behavior when a Spot Instance is interrupted.

Code.documentation: The reason code for the Spot Instance state change.

Message.documentation: The message for the Spot Instance state change.

Code.documentation: The status code. For a list of status codes, see Spot Status Codes in the Amazon EC2 User Guide for Linux Instances.

Message.documentation: The description for the status code.

UpdateTime.documentation: The date and time of the most recent status update, in UTC format (for example, YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ).

SpotInstanceStatus.documentation: Describes the status of a Spot Instance request.

MaxPrice.documentation: The maximum hourly price you're willing to pay for the Spot Instances. The default is the On-Demand price.

SpotInstanceType.documentation: The Spot Instance request type. For RunInstances, persistent Spot Instance requests are only supported when InstanceInterruptionBehavior is set to either hibernate or stop.

BlockDurationMinutes.documentation: The required duration for the Spot Instances (also known as Spot blocks), in minutes. This value must be a multiple of 60 (60, 120, 180, 240, 300, or 360).

ValidUntil.documentation: The end date of the request. For a one-time request, the request remains active until all instances launch, the request is canceled, or this date is reached. If the request is persistent, it remains active until it is canceled or this date and time is reached. The default end date is 7 days from the current date.

InstanceInterruptionBehavior.documentation: The behavior when a Spot Instance is interrupted. The default is terminate.

AllocationStrategy.documentation:
Indicates how to allocate the target Spot Instance capacity across the Spot Instance pools specified by the EC2 Fleet.

If the allocation strategy is lowestPrice, EC2 Fleet launches instances from the Spot Instance pools with the lowest price. This is the default allocation strategy.

If the allocation strategy is diversified, EC2 Fleet launches instances from all the Spot Instance pools that you specify.

If the allocation strategy is capacityOptimized, EC2 Fleet launches instances from Spot Instance pools with optimal capacity for the number of instances that are launching.

InstanceInterruptionBehavior.documentation: The behavior when a Spot Instance is interrupted. The default is terminate.

InstancePoolsToUseCount.documentation: The number of Spot pools across which to allocate your target Spot capacity. Valid only when AllocationStrategy is set to lowestPrice. EC2 Fleet selects the cheapest Spot pools and evenly allocates your target Spot capacity across the number of Spot pools that you specify.

SingleInstanceType.documentation: Indicates that the fleet uses a single instance type to launch all Spot Instances in the fleet.

SingleAvailabilityZone.documentation: Indicates that the fleet launches all Spot Instances into a single Availability Zone.

MinTargetCapacity.documentation: The minimum target capacity for Spot Instances in the fleet. If the minimum target capacity is not reached, the fleet launches no instances.

MaxTotalPrice.documentation: The maximum amount per hour for Spot Instances that you're willing to pay.

SpotOptions.documentation: Describes the configuration of Spot Instances in an EC2 Fleet.

AllocationStrategy.documentation:
Indicates how to allocate the target Spot Instance capacity across the Spot Instance pools specified by the EC2 Fleet.

If the allocation strategy is lowestPrice, EC2 Fleet launches instances from the Spot Instance pools with the lowest price. This is the default allocation strategy.

If the allocation strategy is diversified, EC2 Fleet launches instances from all the Spot Instance pools that you specify.
